qas.question: Why are there so few surviving mosaics from the Komnenian period?
Where is the only existing 12th century mosaic in Constantinople?
What deity does the 12th century mosaic in the Hagia Sophia depict?
The empress Eirene had what color hair?
The only surviving mosaic from the Komnenos dynasty outside Constantinople is in what church?

context: There are very few existing mosaics from the Komnenian period but this paucity must be due to <a0_0>accidents of survival<a0_0/> and gives a misleading impression. The only surviving 12th-century mosaic work in Constantinople is a panel in <a1_0>Hagia Sophia<a1_0/> depicting Emperor John II and Empress Eirene with <a2_0>the Theotokos<a2_0/> (1122–34). The empress with her long braided hair and rosy cheeks is especially capturing. It must be a lifelike portrayal because Eirene was really a <a3_0>red<a3_0/>head as her original Hungarian name, Piroska shows. The adjacent portrait of Emperor Alexios I Komnenos on a pier (from 1122) is similarly personal. The imperial mausoleum of the Komnenos dynasty, the Pantokrator Monastery was certainly decorated with great mosaics but these were later destroyed. The lack of Komnenian mosaics outside the capital is even more apparent. There is only a "Communion of the Apostles" in the apse of <a4_0>the cathedral of Serres<a4_0/>.
